charpter.char_desc: A set of seven poems.

section_text: Which is better, a clock that is right only once a year, or a clock that is right twice every day?

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: "The latter," you reply, "unquestionably." Very good, now attend.

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: I have two clocks: one doesn't go at all, and the other loses a minute a day: which would you prefer? "The losing one," you answer, "without a doubt."

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: Now observe: the one which loses a minute a day has to lose twelve hours, or seven hundred and twenty minutes before it is right again, consequently it is only right once in two years, whereas the other is evidently right as often as the time it points to comes round, which happens twice a day.

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.

book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.

book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: "Ah, but," you say, "what's the use of its being right twice a day, if I ca'n't tell when the time comes?"

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: Why, suppose the clock points to eight o'clock, don't you see that the clock is right at eight o'clock? Consequently, when eight o'clock comes round your clock is right.

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: Very good, then you've contradicted yourself twice: now get out of the difficulty as best you can, and don't contradict yourself again if you can help it.

book.name: Poems, Puzzles, and Stories of Lewis Carroll
book.author: Lewis Carroll
book.source:
Source:
      This book was compiled by the Florida Center for Instructional Technology and includes passages from multiple sources. Please refer to the passage pages for further source information.
book.keywords: age, alliteration, folk story, nonsense, rhyme, rhythm, riddle, time, trickery
book.desc: Lewis Carroll, author of Alice in Wonderland and Through the Looking Glass, also compoosed logic puzzles, riddles, and satirical poems. This collection includes several that were including in longer works and those intended to stand alone.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: You might go on to ask, "How am I to know when eight o'clock does come? My clock will not tell me." Be patient: you know that when eight o'clock comes your clock is right, very good; then your rule is this: keep your eye fixed on your clock, and the very moment it is right it will be eight o'clock.

charpter.char_desc: The author uses the example of two faulty clocks to make a point.

section_text: There, that'll do; the more you argue the further you get from the point, so it will be as well to stop.
